articles.author: Alexander Neitzel
articles.description:
Most devs monitor one thing:  
Is my app up?
And while that‚Äôs a good start ‚Äî it‚Äôs just the tip of the stack.
If you‚Äôre not monitoring the services around your app, you‚Äôre flying blind.
Here‚Äôs what I mean ‚Äî and how to fix it üëá
DNS outages (users can't resolve your domain = you're offline)
Email delivery failures (SMTP down = no password resets)
Third-party APIs (Stripe, OpenAI, Auth0, etc.)
Database connectivity
Port availability (especially for self-hosted services)
Keyword responses (check for specific phrases in API/HTML)
SSL certificate expiration
Each of these can cause downtime even if your app is 100% up.
I use Garmingo Status ‚Äî it lets me monitor way more than just ‚Äúis my website up?‚Äù
Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve set up:
‚úÖ HTTP/HTTPS checks for frontend & backend
‚úÖ Ping & Port checks for internal services
‚úÖ DNS monitoring (A, AAAA, CNAME, MX‚Ä¶)
‚úÖ Keyword checks (e.g. ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, ‚Äú200 OK‚Äù, login form present)
‚úÖ Certificate monitoring
‚úÖ Uptime + incident logs
‚úÖ Public status page for transparency
It takes minutes to configure, and it‚Äôs all in one place.
You can‚Äôt fix what you‚Äôre not watching.
The worst kind of outage is the one where:
Everything looks fine on your end‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶but users are still getting 404s or no emails.
Don‚Äôt let silent failures wreck your reliability.
Garmingo Status has a forever free plan

(no credit card, no vendor lock-in).
It lets you monitor everything around your app ‚Äî not just the app itself.
üëâ https://garmingo.com/status#free-demo
Curious: What‚Äôs the weirdest thing you monitor?

Let me know in the comments üëá
articles.title: How to Monitor Everything That‚Äôs Not Just Your App (DNS, Email, APIs, DBs‚Ä¶)

articles.author: FUNDAMENTOS JAVA
articles.description:
1 Problemas de infer√™ncia com lambdas encadeados
usuarios.sort(Comparator.comparingInt(Usuario::getPontos)


Lambda equivalente pode n√£o compilar:
usuarios.sort(Comparator.comparingInt(u -> u.getPontos())


2 Solu√ß√µes para compilar lambdas encadeados
Explicitando o tipo no lambda:
usuarios.sort(Comparator.comparingInt((Usuario u) -> u.getPontos())


Quebrando o encadeamento:
Comparator<Usuario> comparator = Comparator.comparing(u -> u.getPontos());


For√ßando tipo gen√©rico do m√©todo:
usuarios.sort(Comparator.<Usuario>comparingInt(u -> u.getPontos())


3 Prefer√™ncia por method reference
Usado principalmente em interfaces fluentes como Comparator.reversed().
Exemplo: m√©todo reversed()
usuarios.sort(Comparator.comparingInt(Usuario::getPontos).reversed());
Lambda precisa de tipo expl√≠cito:
usuarios.sort(Comparator.comparingInt((Usuario u) -> u.getPontos()).reversed());
Exemplo: ExemploInferenciaEncadeamento.java
articles.title: Limita√ß√µes da infer√™ncia no lambda

articles.author: FUNDAMENTOS JAVA
articles.description:
1 Lambda precisa ter um tipo funcional
Exemplo que n√£o compila:
Object o = () -> {


2 Lambda atribu√≠da corretamente a uma interface funcional
Runnable r = () -> {


3 Lambda passada diretamente como argumento
new Thread(() -> {


O construtor Thread(Runnable r) espera um Runnable, ent√£o o compilador infere que a lambda √© Runnable.
4 Target Type
O tipo esperado pelo compilador baseado no contexto √© chamado de Target Type.
O Target Type permite:
Inferir o tipo da express√£o lambda;


Reconhecer que uma mesma lambda pode representar diferentes interfaces funcionais.



Exemplo com mesma express√£o lambda e diferentes tipos:
Callable<String> c = () -> "retorna uma String";


Na primeira linha: Callable.
5 O mesmo acontece com Method Reference
A method reference tamb√©m usa Target Type para infer√™ncia.
Exemplo com method reference
Callable<String> c = callable::call;


A mesma refer√™ncia callable::call pode se adaptar a diferentes interfaces.
6 Diferen√ßa entre Lambda e Method Reference
Al√©m disso, √© permitida a convers√£o entre interfaces funcionais compat√≠veis.
Exemplo: ExemploTargetType.java
articles.title: Qual √© o tipo de uma express√£o Lambda?

articles.author: Lindiwe Dokotala
articles.description:
Hi everyone,
Have you ever wondered why speed and reliability are paramount to online success? Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) have emerged as critical technology powering the Internet. But what exactly are CDNs, and why have they become essential to our online experience?
A Content Delivery Network is a geographically distributed group of servers that work together to provide fast delivery of internet content. By placing servers at strategic locations worldwide, CDNs bring content closer to users, significantly reducing the time it takes to load websites, stream videos, or download files.
Think of a CDN like a network of ATMs. Instead of traveling across town to withdraw money from a single bank location (which would create long lines and delays), ATMs are placed on nearly every corner, ‚Ä¶
articles.title: How CDNs Make the Internet Faster for Everyone

"Clarify what, exactly, Kyle?"


You spent six hours polishing that pull request until it gleamed like a bald man‚Äôs head at noon. You added diagrams. You added comments. You even used complete sentences.
And then Kyle, the human version of an unsaved Google Doc, comments:
"Kinda confusing, tbh."
Cue the emotional dumpster fire.

Cue the spiral:
"Guess I‚Äôm just a failure wrapped in skin."

"Maybe if people had two brain cells to rub together..."

That gut-punch you‚Äôre feeling? Senior engineers just call it Tuesday.

"If I were good enough, nobody would ever need to correct me."
Buckle up, champ: That‚Äôs not how humans work.
Feedback isn‚Äôt an indictment of your talent. It‚Äôs not a scarlet l‚Ä¶
articles.title: Feedback Isn‚Äôt Failure. It‚Äôs a Debugging Tool.

articles.author: Leonardo Melo Santos
articles.description:
Est√° precisando usar o Nginx como ferramenta de API Gateway e n√£o sabe o passo a passo para testar este cen√°rio?
Este artigo tem o objetivo de compartilhar um passo a passo, onde voc√™ poder√° instalar o Nginx no seu Linux e simular API Gateway:
Seguem os passos:
1) Instale as depend√™ncias necess√°rias
Antes de compilar o Nginx, voc√™ precisar√° instalar algumas ferramentas e bibliotecas. Para isso, execute os dois comandos abaixo:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y build-essential libpcre3 libpcre3-dev zlib1g zlib1g-dev libssl-dev wget
2) Baixe o c√≥digo-fonte do Nginx
Acesse ao endere√ßo https://nginx.org/en/download.html e baixe a vers√£o mais est√°vel do NGINX. Em seguida, descompacte o arquivo baixado.
3) Compile o Nginx
Para compilar o Nginx, execute os tr√™s comandos abaixo:
Configure o processo de compila√ß√£o:
./configure --sbin-path=/usr/local/nginx/nginx --conf-path=/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf --pid-path=/usr/local/nginx/nginx.pid
Compile o c√≥digo-fonte:
make
Instale o Nginx:
sudo make install
4) Levante suas aplica√ß√µes que ser√£o usadas no Gateway
No exemplo deste cen√°rio, foram levantadas duas aplica√ß√µes:
http://localhost:3001
http://localhost:3002
5) Configue da forma como deseja
Edite o arquivo "/usr/local/nginx/nginx.conf". No exemplo abaixo foram configurados:
Porta do Nginx √© a 8081, portanto ser√° digitado no navegador o endere√ßo "http://localhost:8081"
Dois endpoints "myapp1" e "myapp2", em que cada um deles ser√° endere√ßado para aplica√ß√µes/endere√ßos diferentes

6) Inicie o Nginx
sudo /usr/local/nginx/nginx
Obs.: Quando quiser parar o Nginx, execute o comando abaixo:
sudo kill -QUIT $(cat /usr/local/nginx/nginx.pid)
articles.title: Usando o Nginx como API gateway no Linux

articles.description:
When setting up an email account on your smartphone, you‚Äôll often encounter two main protocols: POP3 and IMAP. While both allow you to access your emails, they work very differently‚Äîand choosing the wrong one can lead to frustration, like missing emails or poor synchronization across devices.  
This guide explains the key differences between POP3 and IMAP, their pros and cons, and which one you should use for your needs.  
What Are POP3 and IMAP?



  
  
  1. POP3 (Post Office Protocol 3)




How it works: Downloads emails from the server to your device and typically deletes them from the server afterward.


Best for: Users who primarily check email on a single device and want offline access.


Drawback: Poor synchronization across multiple devices.




  
  
  2. IMAP (Internet Message A‚Ä¶
articles.title: Difference between POP3 vs. IMAP and Which Email Protocol Should You Use on Your Phone?

Jason Safaiyeh „Éª Apr 29

articles.title: [Boost]

articles.author: Jason Safaiyeh
articles.description:
Quick heads-up:


If you already know you need to file French crypto paperwork for your iOS app, you can generate it automatically here: Nova Store.
If you‚Äôve ever tried distributing your iOS app to France and hit weird legal or compliance issues - you're not alone.
Most devs don‚Äôt realize that just using HTTPS, APNs, Keychain, or CryptoKit puts your app in a category that requires a cryptography declaration under French law. No one warns you, but Apple still expects you to comply.
This comes from D√©cret n¬∞2007-663 ‚Äî a French regulation that classifies basic cryptographic usage (like SSL/TLS) as ‚Äúmeans of cryptology.‚Äù
If you don‚Äôt file the required documents with ANSSI, your app can get blocked or delayed.
Technically, you need to:
Fill out a 6-page declaration form (in French)
Attach detailed technical descriptions of your app‚Äôs crypto functions
Email it manually to the French government (ANSSI) before launch
Hope it‚Äôs accepted without requiring revisions
Most devs find out about this only when they want to launch.
Rather than spend hours digging through French legal forms, you can now generate the full required documentation automatically.
I built Nova Store to handle this.
Submit it directly to ANSSI without worrying about legal mistakes
It saves hours of time - and helps you avoid customs or compliance issues down the line.
articles.title: Why You Can‚Äôt Deploy Your iOS App to France (and How to Fix It in 5 Minutes)

articles.author: alakkadshaw
articles.description:
The direct peer to peer communication is often blocked by NATs that is Network Address translation, NATs hide device IP addresses behind the routers and for security and IP management.
This creates a challenge to create a direct peer-to-peer connection between devices. The STUN servers provide a solution by letting devices learn their own public IP addresses and port numbers as seen by external networks
This article is going to explain
    What is a STUN server?
    Why is it necessary?
    How it works and its important role in enabling modern technologies like WebRTC and VoIP

NAT maps multiple private IP address inside a local or private network to a single IP address.
NATs are basically a workaround, that was invented to preserve limited IPv4 address space. they also come with a basic ‚Ä¶
articles.title: What is a Stun server?

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Adrian Zmudzinski
articles.description:
Cryptocurrency compliance firm Bitrace found that $649 billion worth of stablecoins flowed through addresses classified as high-risk in 2024, according to an April 29 report.
Bitrace defines high-risk blockchain addresses as those used by illegal entities to receive, transfer or store stablecoins.
Crypto compliance firms typically score crypto wallet addresses based on their likelihood of involvement in illicit activities. The higher the risk, the higher the likelihood of foul play, and the less likely compliant crypto businesses are to accept the assets.
Per the report, the amount accounted for roughly 5.14% of all stablecoin transaction volume in 2024. This is down 0.8% from 5.94% the previous year, but significantly higher than the 2.8% reported in 2022 and 1.63% in 2021.
Proportion of ‚Ä¶
articles.title: $649B stablecoin transfers linked to illicit activity in 2024: Report

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Sasha Shilina
articles.description:
What is digital identity?            
            
                
Your digital identity is the fingerprint you leave across the internet, a living map of who you are.
Your digital identity is more than just your name or email; it stretches from your social media profiles and crypto wallet addresses to your device fingerprints and even the rhythms of your daily browsing habits. In the fast-moving world of cryptocurrency, where identity and financial access often overlap, digital identity theft isn‚Äôt just a nuisance; it‚Äôs an open door to your assets.¬†

Without strong protection, even small pieces of stolen information can be stitched into a full profile, giving cybercriminals everything they need to impersonate you, seize your funds or lock you out of your accounts.
What many don‚Äôt realize‚Ä¶
articles.title: Your digital identity got stolen ‚Äî Now what?
